entry.et: Middle English bersten, from Old English berstan; akin to Old High German brestan to burst

def.dt: :to break open, apart, or into pieces usually from impact or from pressure from within
:to give way from an excess of emotion my heart will burst
:to give vent suddenly to a repressed emotion burst into tears burst out laughing
:to emerge or spring suddenly burst out of the house burst onto the scene
:to be filled to the breaking point bursting with excitement a crate bursting with fruit
:to cause to burst burst a balloon
:to force open (as a door or a way) by strong or vigorous action
:to flood over the river burst its banks
:to produce by or as if by bursting
:to be larger, fuller, or more crowded than could reasonably have been anticipated
:a sudden intense effort a burst of speed
:the duration of fire in one engagement of the mechanism of an automatic firearm
:a visible puff accompanying the explosion of a shell
